comments.raw_text:
Popups are a pain in the ass. One way we could really disincentiveice sites from using them would be to open the popup as an overlay on top of the page itself. Just like we do for alerts.

In this overlay we can add UI which lets the user blacklist the site from opening any more popups as well as whitelist the site to always allow "real" popups. The latter can be useful for intranet apps and other sites that the user knows and trusts and which uses popups.

We could also have UI which lets the user "tear" out the overlay into a real window (this could be using drag'n'drop, but doesn't have to).

Note that the implementation should be somewhat simpler than for alerts as we don't have to worry about spinning event loops or anything like that. The page which opened the popup can run normally in the background, however the graying out would prevent the user from interacting with the page.

comments.text:
IIRC, one thing we should check on is how often these popups are triggered through Flash. I'm not sure if we know the origin tab in that case. And, probably, weigh it against just blocking popups more aggressively + better UI to opening/whitelisting popups that are actually desired.

But I do very much like the idea. :)

comments.raw_text: Sounds pretty good.  I guess the caveat is that if we provide a menu on an embedded pop-up to do things like tear away, we may also consider adding this to regular notifications for consistency.
